2. A 65-year-old man presents with persistent diarrhea, generalized weakness, and occasional episodes of hyperglycemia over the past four months. He also notes persistent nausea and early satiety, along with unexplained weight loss of about 10 pounds. On examination, he has mild anemia and skin flushing on his face and upper chest. Laboratory tests reveal elevated fasting somatostatin levels, along with hypochlorhydria and mild hyperglycemia. Imaging studies, including an abdominal MRI, demonstrate a 2.5 cm lesion in the proximal duodenum without distant metastases. Upper endoscopy identifies a submucosal tumor near the ampulla of Vater; biopsy confirms a somatostatin-producing neuroendocrine tumor. Additionally, gallbladder ultrasound shows the presence of multiple small gallstones. The constellation of symptoms and findings leads to the diagnosis of duodenal somatostatinoma, and the patient is being evaluated for surgical removal.

output:

I keep having stomach problems, like nausea and feeling full all the time, and I notice I’ve lost about 10 pounds without trying. I also get these flashes or flushes on my face sometimes, and I just feel kind of off overall.
